question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
When the base-$b$ number $11011_b$ is multiplied by $b-1$, then $1001_b$ is added, what is the result (written in base $b$)?
inference:
$11011_b = 1b^4 + 1b^3 + 0b^2 + 1b^1 + 1b^0 = b^4 + b^3 + b + 1$
$b-1$
$ (b^4 + b^3 + b + 1)(b-1) = b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 = b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1$
$1001_b = 1b^3 + 0b^2 + 0b^1 + 1b^0 = b^3 + 1$
So, $(b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1) + (b^3 + 1) = b^5 + b^2$
$b^5 + b^2 = b^5 + b^2$
Writing this in base $b$, we have $100000_b + 0001_b = 100000_b+00b^2 + 0b + 1 = 100001_b + 00b^2$.

Since this is written as a base $b$ number, the highest power of $b$ can be $b^5$ or $b^4$.  So, we need $b \ge 2$.  The expression is $b^5 + b^2$

If we have $b = 2$, then we have $2^5 + 2^2 = 32 + 4 = 36_{10}$.
To write this in base 2, $36_{10} = 2^5 + 2^2 = 100100_2$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{100001_b}$
ground_truth:
We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align*}
11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\
&= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\
&= b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1.
\end{align*}Now $$1001_b = b^3 + 1,$$so when we add this to the result above, we get $b^5+b^2$, which is written in base $b$ as $\boxed{100100}$.

Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
&& 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\
\times &&&&&& (b-1) \\
\hline
&& (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\
\\
\\
& \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
+ &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\
\hline
& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0
\end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.

We can write out what $11011_b$ means in terms of powers of $b$: $$11011_b = b^4+b^3+b+1.$$Multiplying this by $b-1$ gives \begin{align*}
11011_b &= (b-1)b^4 + (b-1)b^3 + (b-1)b + (b-1) \\
&= b^5 - b^4 + b^4 - b^3 + b^2 - b + b - 1 \\
&= b^5 - b^3 + b^2 - 1.
\end{align*}Now $$1001_b = b^3 + 1,$$so when we add this to the result above, we get $b^5+b^2$, which is written in base $b$ as $\boxed{100100}$.

Instead of taking this algebraic approach, you can also think in terms of base-$b$ long arithmetic (note that each $(b-1)$ below represents a single digit): $$\begin{array}{r *5{c@{~}}c}
&& 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\
\times &&&&&& (b-1) \\
\hline
&& (b-1) & (b-1) & 0 & (b-1) & (b-1) \\
\\
\\
& \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(0)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) & \stackrel{1}{\phantom{(}0\phantom{)}} & \stackrel{1}{(b-1)} & (b-1) \\
+ &&& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\
\hline
& 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 0
\end{array}$$Note that no carries are needed in the multiplication step, since $b-1$ is a digit in base $b$. Carries are needed in the addition step, since $(b-1)+1=10_b$.
